etymologies: Old English wæter (noun), wæterian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch water, German Wasser, from an Indo-European root shared by Russian voda (compare with vodka), also by Latin unda ‘wave’ and Greek hudōr ‘water’

definitions: a colorless, transparent, odorless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms.

notes.text: Water is a compound of oxygen and hydrogen (chemical formula: H₂O) with highly distinctive physical and chemical properties: it is able to dissolve many other substances; its solid form (ice) is less dense than the liquid form; its boiling point, viscosity, and surface tension are unusually high for its molecular weight, and it is partially dissociated into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions

shortDefinitions: colourless, transparent, odourless liquid

definitions: water as supplied to houses or commercial establishments through pipes and taps

examples.text: each bedroom has a washbasin with hot and cold water
water pipes

shortDefinitions: water as supplied to houses or commercial establishments

definitions: one of the four elements in ancient and medieval philosophy and in astrology (considered essential to the nature of the signs Cancer, Scorpio, and Pisces)

examples.text: a water sign

shortDefinitions: one of four elements in astrology

definitions: the water of a mineral spring as used medicinally for bathing in or drinking

examples.text: resorts where southerners came to take the waters

shortDefinitions: water of mineral spring

definitions: a solution of a specified substance in water

examples.text: ammonia water

shortDefinitions: solution of specified substance in water

definitions: a stretch or area of water, such as a river, sea, or lake

examples.text: the lawns ran down to the water's edge

shortDefinitions: stretch or area of water

definitions: the surface of an area of water

examples.text: she ducked under the water

shortDefinitions: surface of area of water

definitions: found in, on, or near areas of water

examples.text: a water plant

shortDefinitions: found in, on, or near areas of water

definitions: the water of a particular sea, river, or lake

examples.text: the waters of Hudson Bay
the government are taking us into unknown waters with these changes in the legislation

shortDefinitions: water of particular sea or lake

definitions: an area of sea regarded as under the jurisdiction of a particular country

examples.text: Japanese coastal waters

shortDefinitions: area of sea under jurisdiction of particular country

definitions: urine

examples.text: drinking alcohol will make you need to pass water more often

shortDefinitions: urine

definitions: the amniotic fluid surrounding a fetus in the womb, especially as discharged in a flow shortly before birth

examples.text: I think my waters have broken

shortDefinitions: amniotic fluid surrounding fetus in womb

definitions: the quality of transparency and brilliance shown by a diamond or other gem.
shortDefinitions: quality of transparency and brilliance shown by diamond

definitions: capital stock that represents a book value greater than the true assets of a company.
shortDefinitions: capital stock representing book value greater than true assets

definitions: pour or sprinkle water over (a plant or area) in order to encourage plant growth

examples.text: I went out to water the geraniums

shortDefinitions: pour or sprinkle water over

definitions: give a drink of water to (an animal)

examples.text: they stopped to water the horses and to refresh themselves

shortDefinitions: give drink of water to

definitions: (of a river) flow through (an area of land)

examples.text: the valley is watered by the Pines River

shortDefinitions: (of river) flow through

definitions: take a fresh supply of water on board (a ship or steam train)

examples.text: the ship was watered and fresh livestock taken aboard

shortDefinitions: take fresh supply of water on board

definitions: (of the eyes) become full of moisture or tears

examples.text: Rory blinked, his eyes watering

shortDefinitions: fill with tears

definitions: (of a person's mouth) produce saliva, typically in response to the sight or smell of appetizing food

examples.text: the smell of frying bacon made Hilary's mouth water

shortDefinitions: produce saliva

definitions: dilute or adulterate (a drink, typically an alcoholic one) with water

examples.text: staff at the club had been watering down the drinks

shortDefinitions: dilute or adulterate drink with water

definitions: make a statement or proposal less forceful or controversial by changing or leaving out certain details

examples.text: the army's report of its investigation was considerably watered down

shortDefinitions: make statement or proposal less forceful

definitions: increase (a company's debt, or nominal capital) by the issue of new shares without a corresponding addition to assets.
shortDefinitions: increase company's debt or capital by issue of shares
